The text on the painting identifies Euphrosina as the wife of Freiherr von Wilferstorf, but her origin is emphasized by the word "born as".

The Portrait of Euphrosina von Wilferstorf is a classic portrait of aristocracy, in which the jewellery, the clothing and the curtain in the background all testify to the wealth and importance of the personality.

The GrazMuseum preserves two Baroque representative portraits of 26-year-old Jonas von Wilferstorf and his wife Euphrosina von Wilferstorf, which together form a unit.

the man in the painting first built the Withalm Coliseum in Graz, and then in Ljubljana.
This portrait was part of the GrazMuseum's exhibition "Graz Portraits." in 2008.

the man in the painting set an even greater milestone in Styrian architectural and construction history in 1846, when he began in Graz with the construction of the Iron House, one of the first examples of cast iron construction in Europe.

In 1817, the man in the painting became a master builder in Graz, where he became known for good work execution and innovation: he invented a system for removing odors from toilets and paving roads with oak blocks.
